trial_identification.studytitle: The effect of cryotherapy on force reproduction of the ankle
trial_identification.scientifictitle: The effect of cryotherapy applied on the ankle of young adults on isometric force reproduction - a cross over randomised controlled trial

conditions.healthcondition: The effect of cryotherapy on proprioception of the ankle when applied on the plantar surface and dorsum of the foot in healthy young adults

interventions.interventions: Cryotherapy will be applied to the plantar surface and dorsum of the foot for 20 minutes and reapplied for another 10 minutes after a interval of approximately 15 minutes. There will be a washout interval of at least 48 hours between the two evaluation moments for both groups (group A: cryotherapy -washout - no cryotherapy; group B: no cryotherapy - washout - cryotherapy). The cryotherapy will be applied by immersing the plantar surface of the foot on iced water (about 2cm deep) and keeping the toes out of the water and applying ice packs on the dorsum of the foot.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Capacity to reproduce (replicate) force of 20% and 50% of maximum isometric plantar flexion. The participant will be asked to sit on a chair and place the foot on a flat apparatus that will be attached to a load cell that can register force. The participant will be asked to perform a maximum voluntary isometric dorsiflexion (MVID) and the result of this MVID will be used to calculate the 20% and 50%. The capacity to reproduce force will be calculated after 10 test trials for each percentage. Up to 4 familiarisation trials will be allowed prior to the 10 test trials
primaryOutcome.timepoint: After cryotherapy application (while temperature is still low)

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Injury on lower limbs for the 6 weeks prior to data collection Skin alergic reaction to cryotherapy Raynaud's phenomenon Diabetes mellitus Skin rash

trial_design.concealment: One of the researchers, not involved in enrolling participants, will be responsible for the randomisation process will prepare sealed opaque envelopes

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The purpose of the study is to evaluate whether cryotherapy, applied on the foot, can alter the capacity to reproduce a predetermened plantar flexion force. It is possible that cryotherapy will significantly decreased the capacity to feel force on the ankle.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: Comite de Etica em Pesquisa em Seres Humanos da UDESC (Research Ethics Committee in Humans - UDESC)
